content:
I assume the tasks aren't all formatted fully due to the word limit imposed by the CodinGame statement editor, so I won't comment on that for now.

My impression of this puzzle is that there seems to be a lot to do, but very few (if not none) of the tasks actually carry any difficulty. In fact, I think this could be a Medium puzzle the way it's currently set up. This is my evaluation of each of the tasks so far:

- GRAPH: there is no "shortest" path to evaluate; there is only one path in each test case, and each path involves all edges. Graph algorithms such as Dijkstra is not required here.

- ITEMS: standard 0/1 knapsack, unfortunately I think it's brute-forceable due to the small number of items given. The variable names "w" and "v" may not be friendly to those unfamiliar with the knapsack algorithm.

- GUARDS: seems to be a simulation exercise involving at most one guard (at least for most of the test cases, correct me if I'm wrong). A Manhattan distance of >1 seems to be too restrictive of a condition as most loops will terminate immediately / after just a few iterations.

- SAFE: this one is quite interesting, worth keeping.

- PATTERN: this one is resistant to brute-force even for a small number of candidates and is worth keeping. Edit distance might not be friendly to those unfamiliar with the definition, but it's easily google-able.

- HIERARCHY: some test cases (e.g. "Golden Spiral", "Final Meltdown") do not fulfil the required P>C format. Long chains of consecutive P>C end up pointing to the very first element being the root node (I assume "P" means parent and "C" means child).

- BINARY: simple XOR reduction and built-in bit counter will easily solve this task, not worth keeping.

- FACTOR: worth keeping. Here "multiplicity" might not be friendly and may potentially be confusing; see: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2029838/is-there-a-name-notation-for-the-sum-of-the-powers-in-a-prime-factorization.

- WORDS: simple sorting task, not worth keeping.

- SECRET: simple encoding task, not worth keeping.

- NUMS: simple GCD/LCM reduction, not worth keeping.

- FIB: simple, but may be worth keeping I suppose.

- PALSTR: worth keeping; but again, will need inputs of much longer length to avoid brute-force algorithms.

- ROMAN: simple but I think it's worth keeping.

- RLE: simple, not worth keeping UNLESS the original decoded string is meant to contain digits as well (for example, check my clash of code: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1410576a3b7d8c27061b17d991e7afd80354a4)

- ANAGRAM: simple counting exercise, not worth keeping.

- BRACKETS: simple stack solution; I guess it's worth keeping. But the only test cases worth considering are few (e.g. "Network Infiltration", "Number Theory Storm"); the rest of the test cases contain trivial versions of the problem.
This is okay, but there's too many tasks to do, it's fine if it's 3 ish but this shouldn't really be a classic puzzle. Maybe try simplifying?

General
* The variety of tasks is overwhelming. While the story provides a thematic wrapper, it mostly connects a set of otherwise unrelated mini-problems and feels somewhat bolted on. It may be better to let each task stand on its own as an independent puzzle rather than framing them as parts of a single narrative sequence.

Difficulty
* As solving this problem requires familiarity with a wide range of algorithms and techniques, the overall difficulty should be classified as Hard or Very Hard.

Goal
* The term "Phase" is potentially misleading. It suggests a sequential dependency where the output of one phase becomes the input of the next. In reality, after DECODE and PARSE, the remaining tasks are largely independent computations whose results are only combined at the end.
Please avoid the word "Phase" where this dependency does not exist, and clarify explicitly that most tasks are independent.

* The purpose and output of Phase 2 (PARSE) are not clearly connected to the subsequent tasks. It should be stated explicitly that all later tasks read their inputs directly from the parsed key–value data.

* Several input specifications are unclear or underspecified. For example,

  • Some delimiters are not stated.

  • Some text isn't formatted as [[variables]] or {{constants}} for easy identification.
  
  • The expression [[x mod M = R]] is written like a single variable name, which is confusing.

  • The meanings of some variables aren't defined.

  • The input formats aren't always specified (e.g. TX and TY).

* Phase 4 (GRID): The purpose of this task is unclear and seems disconnected from the rest. Please clarify the intent or consider removing it.

* Phase 6 (GUARDS): The coordinate system isn't defined. For example, does moving U increase or decrease the y-coordinate?

* Phase 12 (SORT): If the number of words N is even, how is the "middle" word defined?

* Phases 14 & 15: Abbreviations (GCD and LCM) should be accompanied by their full names.

* Phase 19 (RLE): Is every character of the original (uncompressed) string guaranteed to be a non-digit character? Is every character guaranteed to have a preceding count? Are multi-digit counts allowed?

* Phase 26 (REVERSE): How is a "word" defined? Are words always space-delimited? How should punctuation or multiple spaces (if any) be handled?

Constraints
* The stated maximum encoded input length (12000) exceeds CG's limit (10000), and the actual test inputs never contain more than 2000 characters. Please update the constraint to 2000 to reflect realistic limits.

Stub generator
* Please change 12000 to 2000 for the reason stated above.

Thanks.

thanks for the review. a narrative thing, yes, the tasks are different, but by keeping the shell, they just made it clear that they are independent after analysis
everything is fixed: phase < task, the grid disappeared (only +10201 in the final), the coordinates of the guards are determined (U=Y+1, etc.), gcd/lcm is registered, in rle there is an example with a multi-digit number, only a reverse single space, sorting has (n-1)/2, limit 2000
also had to squeeze a lot, it was too long for cg
Are you saying that the task is not very hard, but impossible?

(continued from above)

- ARRAY: since there's only one query, this task becomes too simple. Not worth keeping unless you intend to introduce multiple queries, in which case a longer array of integers would encourage prefix sum / segment tree-based solutions.

- BINSTR: simple conversion, not worth keeping.

- HEXSTR: simple conversion, not worth keeping.

- TEXT: simple counting exercise, not worth keeping.

- SENTENCE: simple reverse exercise, not worth keeping.

- DUPLIST: simple counting exercise, not worth keeping.

- LUHN: sure, seems google-able enough for those unfamiliar to find out how to implement / reverse the check digit algorithm.

- POWER: math, not worth keeping.

My recommendation here (assuming you want to keep the "chaos" of all this) is to narrow down to at most 10(?) tasks (basically a select few) and really expand on them in the test cases to ensure that each algorithm required of the player is implemented thoroughly and not using some cheap trick based on analysing the inputs of the puzzle.

I sort-of understand the reasoning behind the minimal explanation for each task (notwithstanding the word limit), but there still remains some ambiguity for some of the tasks (as listed above) that should be clarified to a greater extent.
Very detailed, thank you for the review. Did you solve the problem? And in what language?
Maybe I'll complicate things. There are 25 days left, so there's still plenty of time.
I have not attempted a solution just yet; my analysis comes from observing the inputs of the puzzle.
Please review my puzzle.

General
* My original comment still stands. The puzzle feels like a collection of otherwise unrelated mini-problems loosely tied together by a thin narrative wrapper. As written, it still reads like: "Here are several classic algorithms to solve, and there happens to be a story." It's better to let each task stand on its own as an independent puzzle.

* The tasks are underspecified and need more detailed descriptions. The character limit is 5000, while the current statement is only ~1700 characters, so there is ample room to expand the statement. (There will be even more room if some tasks are removed; see below.) You can also use the Input section to provide more details on inputs (also see below).

* I strongly recommend switching the puzzle to WIP status for now to avoid accidental approval or rejection. Significant revisions are needed, and it'd be best to refine everything before publication.

Existing puzzles
* Consider removing the following tasks. Standalone puzzles with the same or similar tasks already exist.

  • {{SAFE}} https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/remainder-fantasy

  • {{PALSTR}} https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/longest-palindrome

  • {{BRACKETS}} https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/brackets-extreme-edition , https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/valid-brackets-in-code

  • {{LUHN}} https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/credit-card-verifier-luhns-algorithm

Difficulty
* The overall difficulty should be classified as Hard, as the problem still assumes familiarity with multiple algorithms and techniques, and the effort required exceeds that of a typical Medium puzzle.

Goal
* Please add "Each line corresponds to one task."

* Please move all constraints into the Constraints section.

* Please assign every parameter a name and format it as a [[variable]].

* GRAPH: Please format "-", ":", "S" and "E" as {{constants}}.

* FINAL: Please format "PATTERN" as a {{constant}}.

* FIB: The word "Fibonacci" is missing in the description.

* Please rewrite all unclear or abbreviated descriptions using complete sentences, including but not limited to:

  • ITEMS: Please expand "Solve 0/1 Knapsack".

  • GUARDS: Please replace "T" with "time" or define it clearly. Please state the time required for each move.

Input
* For every task, please clearly describe each variable's type and meaning. For example (illustrative only):

{{GRAPH}}:
For each edge:
• [[A]] and [[B]]: Single-letter labels for the two vertices.
• [[W]]: Integer for edge weight.

Constraints
* Please specify constraints for every task.

* Please show the task name before the corresponding task-specific constraints. For example,

{{GRAPH}}:
• 1 ≤ number of nodes ≤ 50
• 1 ≤ number of edges ≤ 200
• ??? ≤ [[W]] ≤ ??? (fill in the bounds)
• {{S}} and {{E}} are guaranteed to exist and be connected.

Cases
* Omega (Test 6): Please remove the trailing newline from the output.

* I'll further review the cases once the above issues have been addressed.

Thanks.
It seems that you've updated your puzzle substantially. Is it ready for another review?
yes

General
* May I once again suggest considering splitting the individual tasks into separate puzzles?

As the puzzle grows more complex, it naturally becomes harder to manage and maintain consistent quality. There are many aspects to verify (my own case-checking script already exceeds 200 lines), and it's difficult to ensure clear progression in case difficulty. From a review perspective, it's also challenging to thoroughly validate everything and be fully confident that nothing has been missed.

Task removal
* Consider removing the PATTERN task as there's already an existing puzzle on Levenshtein distance: https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/levenshtein-distance

* Consider removing the FACTOR task as there's already an existing clash with the same task: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/396274fc9376e23154b061de0cc40db8143

* Consider removing the EVAL and POWMOD tasks. These tasks may not meaningfully increase algorithmic depth in languages with built-in support.

Goal
* "Each task below reads its own set of keys from this parsed data": consider replacing "reads" and "keys" with "uses" and "parameters" respectively.

* All task descriptions currently begin with "The key", but that's imprecise. For example, {{GRAPH}} is the key, but its associated value contains the actual data. Please revise the wording.

* GRAPH: Please clarify what "shortest" means. Does it refer to the minimum number of edges or the minimum total path weight? Consider explicitly stating which value to consider and avoiding the word "shortest".

* GUARDS: Please change "a guard has" to "every guard has".

* EVAL: Please show the parentheses characters.

* Step 4: Please format task names in <<bold>> instead of as {{constants}}. (The {{constant}} format is preserved for the [[KEYS]].)

Input
* Please add "in the following order" after "KEY:VALUE".

* Please reformat task names in <<bold>> instead of as {{constants}}, and the keys as {{constants}} (see example below).

* If a variable name is the same as a key, show them separately, e.g. {{TX}} and [[TX]].

* For GRAPH, KNAPSACK and GUARDS, please rewrite the input descriptions for clarity. Example:

<<GRAPH>>: {{GRAPH}} — comma-separated edges, each formatted as [[A]]{{-}}[[B]]{{:}}[[W]] (node names, integer weight).

* Consider simplifying the input format by adopting a consistent delimiter rule, e.g.
  • Always separate elements in [[VALUE]] using semicolons.
  • Separate sub-elements using commas.
  If such a convention is stated upfront, repeated explanations of delimiters can be removed from individual task descriptions (in both the Goal and Input sections).

* KNAPSACK: Please state that [[WEIGHT]] and [[VALUE]] are integers.

* GUARDS: Please state that [[GX]] and [[GY]] are integers.

(character limit almost reached…)

(continued…)

Constraints
* Please format task names in <<bold>> instead of as {{constants}}.

* GRAPH: Please add:
[[A]] and [[B]] consist of alphanumeric characters only.
[[A]] ≠ [[B]] for each edge.
There are no duplicate edges.

* KNAPSACK: Please add:
Each item's [[NAME]] is unique and consists of alphanumeric characters only.

* KNAPSACK: Please move the constraint on [[CAP]] to the end to match the order of appearance in the input.

* GUARDS: Please add:
A solution is guaranteed to exist.

(Counterexample for your reference:
TX = TY = 4
GUARDS = 2,3,URDL;3,5,URDL;4,2,URDL;5,4,URDL)

* PATTERN: Each string contains lowercase English letters only.

* EVAL: Please add:
[[EXPR]] is always valid and does not involve any division by zero.

* LCS: Each string contains lowercase English letters only.

* TOPO: Please add:
[[P]] and [[C]] are single uppercase English letters.
[[P]] ≠ [[C]] for each edge.
There are no isolated edges.

* Please adjust overstated upper bounds to the following to better reflect actual test cases:

  • GRAPH: number of nodes = 20
  • GRAPH: number of edges = 50
  • KNAPSACK: CAP = 100
  • GUARDS: GX, GY, TX, TY = 10
  • PATTERN: length of each string = 20
  • LCS: length of each string = 20
  • TOPO: number of nodes = 10
  • TOPO: number of edges = 10
  • POWMOD: base = 10^7

Cases
* Infiltration (Validator 2) - GUARDS: Please revise guard paths so that they don't return to their original positions after a full cycle, similar to Test 2.

* Storm (Test 7) - GRAPH: Every edge is bilateral, yet the input contains conflicting weights: D-C with weight 1 and C-D with weight 3.

* FACTOR: Test coverage appears imbalanced (only very small or very large values used).

* FIB: Test coverage appears imbalanced (only very small or very large values used).

* [[N]] of the FIB task is the same for Backdoor (Validator 3) and Omega (Test 6).

* All parameters of the PATTERN, LCS, TOPO and POWMOD tasks are the same for Apex (Test 9) and Zenith (Validator 9).

* Please verify that, aside from the cases already mentioned above, there are no additional duplicate cases across all tasks. Cases that are structurally identical (e.g. containing the same graph or equivalent elements but differing only in naming or ordering) should be treated as duplicates.

* Consider shuffling edges in the TOPO task across cases to prevent reliance on input order and improve robustness.

Thanks.
I'm saying that there should be less tasks for a 'very hard' puzzle. Or maybe change it to a harder mode?
and where could it be even more difficult? U have idea?
...hmm... maybe give the instructions in code?
Then why was this done if the essence of the task is chaos? It's the same as giving a hacker the task of hacking you and at the same time explaining everything to him and giving him all the data.
Please review my puzzle.
Thanks. I think it's better to cut down the number of tasks (e.g. remove the easiest tasks) and describe each task better rather than squeezing the descriptions even further.

Better yet, try to make the tasks actually dependent on each other. For example, the output of one task becomes the input (or part of the inputs) of another task. (I don't mean the simple summing up of all results.)

nah thats kinda the opposite of what im going for. "chaos protocol" means chaos independent unrelated tasks thrown at you all at once, like when youre actually hacking and dealing with multiple different systems simultaneously. making them dependent would turn it into a linear pipeline which defeats the theme
the challenge is handling the variety and context switching, not following a chain
I really hope you understand)
I see what you're trying to do, and I get the idea behind it. I just don't think CG is the right place for it.
makes sense, gonna wait for other mods to weigh in before deciding on changes. thanks for the detailed review
Please review my puzzle.
